quotes.text: You guys hit 4 million ARR in the first four weeks. You hit 10 million ARR in the first two months with just 15 people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete growth and team-size data points that set a benchmark for what’s possible with a small team and strong product pull.

quotes.text: A lot of jargon that I like to use to emphasize what we should be striving for is building a minimum lovable product and then building a lovable product and then building an absolutely lovable product.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A memorable product-development framework that reframes MVP thinking around delight and emotional resonance.

quotes.text: Doing a bit of everything. Being a generalist, I think much more important than it used to be. If I'm putting together a product team today, I would really obsess about getting as many skill sets as possible for each person I hire.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Actionable hiring guidance that challenges specialization by prioritizing multi-skill generalists for modern product teams.

quotes.text: People love the product. That's the driver of the growth.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A succinct growth principle emphasizing product love as the primary engine over tactics or headcount.

quotes.text: Whether you're sending marketing campaigns, verification codes or account alerts, you need them to reach users reliably.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Cinch)
quotes.context: Highlights reliability as the core requirement for any customer-communications system across multiple message types.

quotes.text: Over 150,000 businesses, including eight of the top 10 largest tech companies globally use Cinch's API to build messaging, email and calling into their products.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Cinch)
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point and social proof for embedding communications via API.

quotes.text: Rich Communication Services or RCS, think of RCS as SMS 2.0.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Cinch)
quotes.context: Offers a memorable mental model for positioning RCS and why product teams should pay attention.

quotes.text: Every company has different needs depending on its industry, use cases, risk tolerance and user demographics.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Persona)
quotes.context: Frames identity verification as a configurable, context-dependent system rather than a one-size-fits-all solution.

quotes.text: Persona offers flexible building blocks that allow you to build tailored collection and verification flows that maximize conversion while minimizing risks.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Persona)
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to design verification flows as modular components optimized for both conversion and risk.

quotes.topic_title: What Lovable is and who it’s for
quotes.text: I'd say Lovable is your personal AI software engineer. You describe an idea and then you get a fully working product from the AI.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A crisp product mental model that frames AI as an end-to-end builder, not just a coding assistant.

quotes.topic_title: What Lovable is and who it’s for
quotes.text: we are building for this 99% of the population who don't write code.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A clear market focus statement that pushes builders to prioritize non-coders as the primary user base.

quotes.topic_title: What Lovable is and who it’s for
quotes.text: over time, naturally the way to build software is by just talking to an AI.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A forward-looking, counterintuitive claim that suggests conversation will replace traditional software construction workflows.

quotes.topic_title: What Lovable is and who it’s for
quotes.text: So we launched Lovable less than three months ago, and now we have 300,000 monthly active users and 30,000 of those are actually paying and it is growing at the same rates, just almost only through organic word of mouth.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Concrete traction metrics plus a growth channel insight (word of mouth) that practitioners can benchmark against.

quotes.topic_title: What Lovable is and who it’s for
quotes.text: People were saying like, "Oh, you're shipping so fast." And we were all quite frustrated because we wrote our service in this kind of scripting language and then as we started scaling, we were just, no, we have to throw everything away and rewrite it in a more performant way.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A scaling lesson: early speed can hide technical debt that forces a rewrite when growth hits.

quotes.topic_title: Live demo: building an Airbnb clone
quotes.text: Two words, Airbnb clones. That's the prompt.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Shows how starting with an extremely minimal prompt can still yield a high-quality first UI draft, encouraging rapid iteration over over-specification.

quotes.topic_title: Live demo: building an Airbnb clone
quotes.text: The first prompt takes 30 seconds.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A concrete speed benchmark that reframes prototyping expectations and enables much faster product iteration cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Live demo: building an Airbnb clone
quotes.text: I'll just say real quick, I love that this is actually a really good example of why being a good product manager is important. A lot of wasted time happens when you're not clear about the problem you're trying to solve and why you're trying to solve it and all that kind of stuff.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Connects prompt quality to core PM clarity, positioning problem definition as a key lever for efficiency with AI tools.

quotes.topic_title: Live demo: building an Airbnb clone
quotes.text: Explaining exactly what you expect and what you're not getting is even more important with AI than with the humans.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A counterintuitive takeaway that raises the bar for precision and feedback loops when collaborating with AI systems.

quotes.topic_title: Live demo: building an Airbnb clone
quotes.text: So I'll just change the text to buy now and then it instantly changes. It actually changes deep down in the code base, but it's very fast to do that.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Highlights a practical workflow: use visual edits for quick UI fixes while still updating underlying code, reducing iteration friction.

quotes.text: But since they're getting better so fast, I think the best thing for people who are interested in this or interested in just being a part of the future economies, get your hands very dirty with these tools because being in the top 10% in using them is going to absolutely set you apart in the coming months and years.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A concrete career/competitive strategy: deep hands-on practice to become a top-tier user as tools rapidly improve.

quotes.text: It takes a lot to master using tools like Lovable and being very curious and patient and we have something called chat mode where you can just ask to understand like, "How does this work? I'm not getting what I want here, am I missing something? What should I do?"
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A practical workflow tip: use “chat mode” as a learning/debugging loop powered by curiosity and patience.

quotes.text: For example, don't say it doesn't work. Just explain exactly what you're expecting and which parts are working and which parts are not working.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A prompt-writing methodology: specify expected vs. actual behavior to prevent miscommunication and speed iteration.

quotes.text: That's true. It might be more costly with humans.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation: iteration and miscommunication can be cheaper with AI agents than with people.

quotes.text: I think it's all about building a great product.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A simple north-star principle that keeps teams focused on product quality over tactics or hype.

quotes.text: That's what I want more people to be able to do and the best word for a great product is that it's Lovable.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Reframes “great product” into a concrete, memorable quality bar teams can align on.

quotes.text: A lot of jargon that I like to use to emphasize what we should be striving for is building a minimum Lovable product and then building a Lovable product and then building an absolutely Lovable product.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Introduces a staged methodology for iterating product quality beyond the typical MVP framing.

quotes.text: So I took that jargon with me in the company name.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Shows how to encode a product philosophy into branding to reinforce priorities internally and externally.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: from GPT Engineer to Lovable
quotes.text: So I wanted to prove a point and I created an open source tool called GPT Engineer where you write something like create a snake game and then it spits out a lot of code, a little of different files and then opens the snake game.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A practical “prove it with a demo” approach: build a simple, concrete prototype that makes the capability undeniable.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: from GPT Engineer to Lovable
quotes.text: Lovable, earlier was always creating new projects on GitHub when someone used Lovable and we asked them, "Is it fine? How was the limits here?" They said, "Oh, there are no limits." But once we started creating 15,000 projects per day, so there were a lot of usage.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A vivid scale data point (15,000 projects/day) and a lesson about hidden platform limits that only appear at high usage.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: from GPT Engineer to Lovable
quotes.text: It's not to make engineers more productive, which there's a lot of companies using AI to make engineers more productive, Microsoft did with co-pilot and so on. But it is to enable those who have such a hard time finding people who are good at creating software that's been their absolute bottleneck and let them take their ideas and their beliefs into reality.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A contrarian product thesis: the bigger opportunity is expanding who can build software, not just accelerating existing engineers.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: from GPT Engineer to Lovable
quotes.text: So enabling more entrepreneurship and innovation by building the AI software engineer for anyone.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A crisp mission statement that doubles as a product strategy framework: target “anyone,” not just technical users.

quotes.text: There are many scaling laws I would say when you build AI systems and this one in particular is about when you put in more work, the product reliably gets better and better.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Frames a practical “scaling law” for AI products: engineering effort should translate into predictable reliability gains, not just occasional improvements.

quotes.text: What we did was to painstakingly identify places where it got stuck and there is different approaches but address different ways how we do it but address the places where it gets stuck, tune the entire system quantitatively and having a very fast feedback loop to improve it in the areas where it got stuck.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Describes an actionable methodology: systematically find failure points, measure/tune quantitatively, and iterate via tight feedback loops.

quotes.text: Yeah. It introduces some kind of bug and then it's not smart enough to figure out how to get out of that bug.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Pinpoints a concrete “stuck” mode practitioners can target: bug introduction plus inability to recover, a key reliability bottleneck for agentic systems.

quotes.text: So what we did was we identified the most important areas, so specifically adding login, creating data persistence, adding payment with Stripe. Those are the things that we made sure it doesn't get stuck on, for example.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Gives specific high-leverage areas to harden first (auth, persistence, payments), illustrating prioritization of reliability work around common product-critical workflows.

quotes.text: We just hit 1 million ARR in a week and then it kept growing at that pace. It still growing at even faster than that pace.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A concrete growth datapoint that contextualizes the impact of their reliability/scaling focus on rapid revenue acceleration.

quotes.topic_title: How a tiny team drove massive growth
quotes.text: I'd like to take credit of having done everything end to end in the product, but we are building on top of taking the oil here, which we have discovered oil, which is are the foundation models and then what we've done is that we're obsessed about what's the right way to present this to a user.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: treat foundation models as “oil” and focus differentiation on how you package and present them to users.

quotes.topic_title: How a tiny team drove massive growth
quotes.text: What's the interface for the human to get as much out of this as possible? Packaging together, I showed you in the demo how you can add authentication and making this work seamlessly together as a whole.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Actionable product strategy: win by building a seamless end-to-end user experience (not just model access), including real-world needs like auth.

quotes.topic_title: How a tiny team drove massive growth
quotes.text: And then people love the product. That's the driver of the growth. For getting awareness, we've mainly been posting what we've shipped on social media, that's how people know about us.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A practical growth playbook: prioritize product love and drive awareness by consistently sharing shipped updates publicly.

quotes.topic_title: How a tiny team drove massive growth
quotes.text: You want people who can ship really fast and have good taste for what this simple, what's the right abstractions and I think that's what we've done differently and have this obsession for us making it better and better and better.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Hiring/engineering guidance: small teams scale impact by combining speed with taste for simplicity and strong abstractions, plus relentless iteration.

quotes.text: Full disclosure, real estate investing is boring.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing that “boring” can be a feature, not a bug, for long-term investing behavior.

quotes.text: But with real estate and investing there's no drama or adrenaline or excuses to refresh your portfolio every few minutes. Just bland and boring stuff like diversification and dividends.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a practical mental model: reduce emotional triggers to avoid over-trading and focus on fundamentals like diversification and dividends.

quotes.text: The fund holds 1.1 billion dollars worth of institutional caliber real estate managed by team of pros focused on steadily growing your net worth for decades to come, see? Boring.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point and emphasizes the long-horizon approach (“decades”) as the core strategy.

quotes.text: That's the point.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A succinct, memorable takeaway that reinforces the counterintuitive idea that low-drama investing is desirable.

quotes.topic_title: How the team builds Lovable with AI
quotes.text: We have set up lovable so that we can change lovable with itself. We have done that.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A concrete example of using your own product internally (“dogfooding”) to accelerate iteration and validate capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: How the team builds Lovable with AI
quotes.text: So we use the tools that are for developers, not for the 99%, most of the time.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Highlights a pragmatic workflow: even if you build for non-technical users, internal engineering may still rely on specialized dev tooling.

quotes.topic_title: How the team builds Lovable with AI
quotes.text: And everyone uses AI all the time in writing code. It's also in great course for experimentations.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: An operational norm: make AI a default part of coding and experimentation rather than an occasional assist.

quotes.topic_title: How the team builds Lovable with AI
quotes.text: Yeah. I think Cursor is the one that almost everyone uses in the team.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A specific tool choice that indicates what’s working in practice for an AI-heavy engineering workflow.

quotes.topic_title: How the team builds Lovable with AI
quotes.text: Something that's different from I think all the other tools is that it is synchronized with GitHub and that means that you can use Cursor, or the people in your team that want to be more low-level, they can use Cursor and while the people who don't want to mess and set up their local file system and commit to GitHub and so on, they can use Lovable's.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A team-scaling model: connect a no-code/low-code interface to GitHub so different skill levels can collaborate in one workflow.

quotes.text: The packaging for non-technical people is what we aim for and I showed you in the demo that you can edit the text, you can change the colors and so on instantly without having to go into the code editor and without having to wait about 30 seconds for the AI do the full change.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Highlights a differentiation strategy: optimize for instant, non-technical iteration instead of slow AI-driven full rewrites in code.

quotes.text: Something that's different from I think all the other tools is that it is synchronized with GitHub and that means that you can use Cursor, or the people in your team that want to be more low-level, they can use Cursor and while the people who don't want to mess and set up their local file system and commit to GitHub and so on, they can use Lovable's.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Provides an actionable collaboration model: bridge no-code and pro-code workflows via GitHub sync so different skill levels can work in parallel.

quotes.text: Not getting stuck is I think the most important thing for people.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A reliability-first product principle that reframes the core user value as progress continuity rather than feature breadth.

quotes.text: And that's why we entered this space late, we haven't done the same type of marketing as many others and we still, from the people that I talked to, ranked as the one that works most reliably.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Counterintuitive go-to-market claim: prioritize reliability over early entry and heavy marketing to win user preference.

quotes.topic_title: Vision: the last piece of software
quotes.text: So we're building the last piece of software and it is inherently very hard to predict how the world looks like in five years.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A memorable framing (“last piece of software”) paired with uncertainty, useful for setting vision while acknowledging rapid change.

quotes.topic_title: Vision: the last piece of software
quotes.text: But the last piece of software, how I see that is that it's almost instant to go from what you want to change in the product or what product you want to build to having it fully working end-to-end, integrated with any of your existing systems or integrated with the very powerful third-party providers.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Defines the end-state as near-instant, end-to-end product creation with deep integrations—an actionable north star for product/engineering teams.

quotes.topic_title: Vision: the last piece of software
quotes.text: Already today you can just ask, add and chat with OpenAI and then you get the chat with OpenAI in your product.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A concrete example of how quickly third-party capabilities can be embedded, illustrating the practical direction of “instant” building.

quotes.topic_title: Vision: the last piece of software
quotes.text: AIs can do that on an absolutely massive scale and propose changes to a human to say, "Oh, yeah, that sounds like a good change to make it a bit more intuitive."
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Suggests a workflow where AI analyzes user behavior at scale and recommends UX improvements, making analytics-to-action more systematic.

quotes.topic_title: Vision: the last piece of software
quotes.text: it used to be the reverse engineering was the hardest, most valuable skill and now it's figuring out what to build.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian shift in what’s valuable: discovery and product judgment over pure engineering execution.

quotes.text: It feels like what is getting more valuable is being good at figuring out what to build and then knowing if the thing you had built is correct and good and ready.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical framing of future leverage: discovery/decision-making and quality judgment matter more as building gets easier.

quotes.text: Just like is this the thing? Is this going to solve people's problems because the building now is being done more and more and it's interesting, it used to be the reverse engineering was the hardest, most valuable skill and now it's figuring out what to build.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian shift in what’s scarce: from implementation difficulty to problem selection and product judgment.

quotes.text: But they should see themselves as the people who translate the problems that are stated a human, probably, to technical solutions, but they do have to abstract themselves up a few steps, not just looking at in their tech stack like oh I can just do the front end changes.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Actionable role redefinition for engineers: move up the abstraction ladder and translate human problems into technical solutions.

quotes.text: Being a generalist is I think much more important than it used to be.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A clear hiring and career heuristic: breadth is becoming more valuable as tools compress specialized execution work.

quotes.text: And if I'm putting together a product team today, I would re-obsess about getting as many skill sets as possible for each person I hire.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A concrete team-building methodology: prioritize multi-skill individuals to increase team coverage and speed.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring: what they look for and how
quotes.text: I think the most important thing is that people care a lot and they're not just like, "Oh, I'm here for a job. I'm here for being just a passenger on this journey," but everyone should really care about the product, the users and care a ton about the team, how the team works together and that you're always contributing to making the team work more productively together and that care or preferably obsession gets you a very long way and then you do often want to have absolute superpower in some dimension to be able to understand and do as many possible things as possible, have this generalist brain that quickly learns any skill but be super, super good in one dimension.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A clear hiring framework: obsession + team/product care + generalist learning ability paired with one standout “superpower.”

quotes.topic_title: Hiring: what they look for and how
quotes.text: I ask people what they've done before and these people that I'm describing, they have often done something where they care a lot about what they've done before and dig into details about the technical things that they did.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A practical interview method: probe deeply into past work to detect genuine ownership and obsession.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring: what they look for and how
quotes.text: And then we do the normal thing of showing a very hard problem that is a bit unorthodox that someone hasn't seen before preferably and see how they think through thinking research through that.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A concrete evaluation tactic: use novel, unorthodox problems to test real reasoning rather than memorized patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring: what they look for and how
quotes.text: Then something that I think is more uncommon is that we do, I pretty much always have people join the work simulation for at least a day, often a full week.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A high-signal hiring practice: short work trials to assess collaboration and execution in real conditions.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring: what they look for and how
quotes.text: this is the time in human history when you have the most impact for a worked hour and that's why we have to be super ambitious, just up the ambition level
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A contrarian motivation lens that ties hiring intensity and urgency to a belief about historically high leverage per hour.

quotes.text: Just top line? I think identifying what is the biggest bottleneck, what's the biggest problem and iterating fast on saying, "Okay, this is the biggest problem, let's really, really solve that problem."
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A bottleneck-driven prioritization heuristic that keeps teams focused on the single highest-leverage constraint.

quotes.text: And then picking in the next one and not overthinking, not dreaming out the long roadmap, that's my [inaudible 00:48:41].
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Advocates for short-horizon execution over long roadmap planning to maintain speed and adaptability.

quotes.text: And then when we pick one of the problems, we are quite engineering-led. For a product like ours, it's hard to be have product managers that are not engineers say, oh, this is what we should do now because the right solution to the problem might be entangled in things that are technical details.
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: Explains why engineering-led prioritization can be necessary when solutions are tightly coupled to technical architecture.

quotes.text: We do have a big jam board where we have all the main problems and then we have kind of ranked them which else do we focus or when we focus on next or this week? And then we have a demo where we say, "Okay, these are things we ship this week."
quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.context: A lightweight operating cadence: ranked problem board + weekly planning + weekly demos to align and drive shipping.
